string.text: A detailed map of the Dead City, including all known Mercenary fortifications
Doctor's key to a secret stash somewhere in Pripyat

Manual teleportion allowing for fast travel of one or more persons to any point within Chernobyl NPP2. Extremely hard to come across. The principles upon which it operates are as yet unclear. Limited to five teleportations...

Protective Suit. Weight: 18kg. Details: Protects the body from most anomalies and excessive physical damage. The torso is protected by built-in metallic plates. Equipped with an airtight, reinforced plastic helmet and two oxygen bottles. NOTE: Excessive usage will cause the suit to tear, and deteriorate beyond the point of practical usefulness

Protective Suit. Weight: 8 kg. Details: Protects the wearer from weak anomalies and mild physical damage. Equipped with a filtration mask. NOTE: Excessive usage will cause the suit to tear, and deteriorate beyond the point of practical usefulness

Protective suit. Weight: 12 kg. Details: Protects the user from many anomalies and physical damage. Equipped with an airtight helmet and oxygen bottle. NOTE: Excessive usage will cause the suit to tear, and deteriorate beyond the point of practical usefulness

A red SCAPE suit with an airtight helmet. Weight: 11kg. Details: Protects the body from fire, acid, toxic gas, various anomalies, and physical damage. Equipped with two oxygen bottles. NOTE: Excessive usage will cause the suit to tear, and deteriorate beyond the point of practical usefulness

The U.S.S.R. has had a long history of quality military optics. At the end of WWII, the Soviet Army had captured most of the German optical plants, including the Carl Zeiss-Jena factory. They took the technology back to Russia, added their own refinements, and built identical and sometimes even more powerful lenses. For many years these binoculars were strictly for military issue. In the late 1980's, researchers proved that the BPC 8x30 Military Binoculars had surpassed their predecessor, the world-famous Zeiss 8x30's
Simple Anomaly Detector. Emits a Geiger-counter sound when approaching an anomaly. Functions when worn on the belt
Detects the presence of abnormal and aberrational fields, indicating their presence with a warning audio signal. Needs to be out in the open and near the ground to work I.e. On your belt...
'Elite' Anomaly Detector invented by Scientists in the Zone. Detects the presence of abnormal and aberrational fields, and displays them on the user's mini-map. Functions when worn on the belt
Personal Digital Assistant - an indispensable library, communication and navigational device in the Zone
Powerful flashlight. Recharge time improved by using the latest battery technology, and a more efficient transducer

Proudly bearing the name of the eponymous, not to mention notorious bar that sells it, '100 Rads' beer can be simply described as an alcoholic energy drink. Whether it’s better or safer than similar non-branded drinks in the Zone, considering the life expectancy of an average Stalker, depends on how much you trust the Barkeep...

Anonymous, generic beverage carrying no specific name, trademark, nor point of origin, thus removing all responsibility from the seller.\nThe label simply states that it 'Contains caffeine, taurine, and rejuvenating vitamins - ideal for when you need to go just that little bit further! Consumption in excessive quantities can lead to illness or death'
No one knows who manages to bake these loaves in the Zone, but they're not contaminated and seem quite fresh. Well, at least the Stalkers have no complaints about their daily bread...

Brain of the Experienced Controller at Chernobyl NPP2. Extremely rare! Upon successful cranial trepanation and removal of the brain, it acquires elasticity and a spherical form upon contact with the air. It is edible, with many beneficial properties - completely satisfying hunger, reducing radiation, restoring health, and eliminating weariness. Usually extracted by Monolithian field surgeons, they are highly prized items both inside and outside the Zone...
Canned food from Military storehouses throughout the Zone that are raided by experienced Stalkers on a regular basis... And the 'Best before' date is in the future!
A mix of chicken, soya, and possibly sawdust, this distasteful sausage is often, for lack of any other edible option, a Stalker's breakfast, lunch, and dinner all in one takeaway meal...
Vodka made by the GSC company out of Kiev, Ukraine. Goes down easily, and significantly reduces the effects of radiation, but for obvious reasons should be used in moderation...
Lightweight, and able to significantly reduce the effects of radiation. Carrying a few of these can literally make the difference between life and death in the Zone
Bandage, to quickly staunch minor bleeding
An all-purpose medical kit. Used to treat wounds, burns, poisoning, etc of varying severity
An advanced medical kit to treat more extreme cases of physical damage and blood loss. Includes blood coagulant, antibiotics, immunal stimulators, and painkillers

Specialised medical kit designed for working conditions in the Zone. Includes all the contents of an advanced medical kit, plus meds to prevent the development of radiation sickness, eliminate radionuclides, and lower the dosage of accumulated radiation in the body
Jerry can filled with Colloidal Gas

These canisters were used in research laboratories throughout the Zone for a variety of purposes. The contents are usually found to be volatile, flammable, explosive, or unidentified chemical agents...

Robust 20 litre fuel container made from pressed steel. Originally designed in Germany in the 1930's for military use, the development of the 'Jerrycan' was a huge improvement on earlier designs, which required tools and funnels to use
Orange sausage - supposedly with cheese added
Blonde sausage - looks awful, but tastes of honey
Dosimeter - a device measuring the doseage or capacity of ionising radiation. Functions when worn on the belt
Detects the presence of abnormal and aberrational fields, indicating their presence with a warning audio signal. Needs to be out in the open and near the ground to work I.e. On your belt...

Anomaly Detector invented by Zone scientists to detect the presence of abnormal and aberrational fields, and indicate their presence with a warning audio signal, while also displaying their location on the user's mini-map. Functions when worn on the belt
Standard computer disk. The information on it is encrypted, and can only be accessed with a password
Standard engineer's vice. Worn and rusty, but will carry on working forever...
Sakharov's old medical bag. The insignia has almost completely worn off. The Professor claims that it was a gift from the Doctor himself...
Gold medallion once belonging to the Doctor. Apparently, he lost it several years ago, and it has not been seen since...

A disgusting, decaying, slimy clump of densely matted hair formed inside the stomach of a Controller. Guaranteed to induce vomiting just by looking at it, they've been known to lower the vital signs of anybody trying to dispose of one. Undaunted by the experiential data, Professor Sakharov believes he can create a useful artefact from this revolting lump of shit!
Expensive coded lock made from titanium alloy, designed to make both the lock and the code unbreakable, and your stash totally secure

Vial filled with medicine. Contains a tincture of grasses and tree bark. Possesses a rather unpleasant odour, and tastes awful, so should definitely be good for something... It's rumoured that a batch of these vials were lost by the Military at the entrance to the Cordon

Ordinary carrion crow egg. High-protein product that satisfies hunger, raises health a little, and slightly reduces radiation. With the absence of hens and other egg-laying fowl in the Zone, these are considered a delicacy

Concoction of marsh grasses possessing soporific properties and hallucinogenic side-effects. The exact composition is known only to the Doctor himself, and he only uses it to help lost souls gain acceptance into the Stalker community...
Medicine from the Miner. Very similar to that which the Doctor gave me - the one that put me in this bloody Cave in the first place! Maybe if I drink this, I can get the hell out of here...
Battery-powered flashlight. Not popular amongst Stalkers due to the potentially life-threatening inconvenience of having to hold it in one hand...

The Rubik's Cube is a three-dimensional mechanical puzzle invented in 1974 by Hungarian sculptor and professor of architecture, Erno Rubik. Originally called the 'Magic Cube', the puzzle was licensed by Rubik to be sold by Ideal Toys in 1980, and won the German 'Game of the Year' special award for Best Puzzle that year. As of January 2009, 350 million cubes have sold worldwide, making it the world's top-selling puzzle game, and widely considered to be the world's best-selling toy ever. Most likely brought into the Zone by Rookies to keep their minds occupied
Book belonging to the Miner's father. A small volume containing stories about hunting. The book is in poor condition, having been left out in the open for many years...
Antique silver Russian rouble. Dated 1747, so may be quite valuable to the right buyer...
Antique silver Russian rouble. Dated 1749, so could fetch quite a nice price outside the Zone...
Gold Chervonets from the 18th century. Often found in old, abandoned mine shafts and caves
Ancient silver Russian rouble. Outside the Zone, it would demand a hefty price...

Wanderer, I want to warn you. You have two choices. The first - to go further, and seek out a secret doorway. The second - to use my teleporter to return to the Army Warehouses and find my PDA. It contains valuable data on the Zone, and the secret uses of a stationary Teleporter which is activated here, at the Monolith, by means of a Goldfish artefact. I have left a copy of my PDA data on a storage disk with the Miner, who lives in an old cave. If you decide to risk pressing on to Chernobyl, this information will prove useful, if not vital, to you. Good luck.\nStrelok
Manual teleporter left by Strelok. Destination: Army Warehouses

An Accumulator produces an electric current at microwave frequencies and wavelengths that 'stimulates' the molecular structure of devices made of metal. It is produced by immersing a standard 'uneffected' accumulator in a 'Springboard' anomaly at a specific time of day when the conditions are just right. Nobody produces these accumulators commercially, and only the Military have been observed testing and using them to produce an increased rate of fire and general effectiveness of the weapons on which they have been equipped

System activation module and instructions for a new SMART suit, which added notes state was stashed on the roof of one of buildings in the vicinity of the Yantar factory.
The writer goes on to say that he needs to go into hiding, but will stash the upgrade blocks for the suit around the Zone for later retrieval. He does not plan to hide them all at once, but only when he feels strong and safe enough to do so, and this would have the added advantage of preventing the fully-equipped prototype from falling into the wrong hands.
His intended stash points are :
1. On top of a disused railcar in the Wild Territory
2. On the roof of a small building near one of the entrances to Radar, near the aerial structures
3. In the Miner's hiding place, near a box, close to one of the fire barrels
4. In the safe hands of a trader at Clear Sky base in the wetlands.
 
To upgrade, do the following in this order:
1. Install the system activation module, and test the suit. Firmware ID should now be SKAT15-M
2. Install the first upgrade block, and test the suit. Firmware ID should now be SKAT15-M1
3. Install the second upgrade block, and test the suit. Firmware ID should now be SKAT15-M2
4. Install the third upgrade block, and test the suit. Firmware ID should now be SKAT15-M3
With each upgrade, the suit acquires more advanced properties.
 
After the second upgrade has been installed, the suit's LifeGuard system will need to draw its power from Black Energy artefacts, which are created by the Zone's emissions. These can be found in the wild after an emission, or obtained from Professor Sakharov.
The energy from this artefact will be fully depleted after two full hours (Zone Time) of use, after which ALL functions of the suit will deteriorate, including its ability to protect the wearer from external damage.
The LifeGuard system will reactivate once another Black Energy artefact is sourced on the wearer.
If the suit's protective properties have been reduced, it may be possible to mend the damage using a standard Armor repair kit. However, if the suit is left without power for too long, its Armor control system may fail to reboot, effectively rendering its basic functions useless.
To conserve energy, the LifeGuard system may be disabled and re-enabled in the suit's Advanced Options menu

Manual teleporter with enhanced capabilities. Two similar examples were produced several years ago, based on the use of items found suspended in a 'Lift' anomaly. The main reason for its disappearance is because this anomaly is quite rare. The second is that it requires a fair amount of practice to use correctly, and usually results in the permanent disappearance of anyone using it for the first time...

Incomplete manual for the 'Lift' teleport. Although practically incomprehensible, these instructions may be put to good use by someone with the right technical skills, and a considerable amount of luck...

Colonel Petrenko's hip flask. Presented to him for exemplary service in battle in Afghanistan, where he was the sole surviving member of the infamous '9th Company'. Somehow, it got lost here in the Zone. It is easily recognizable, decorated as it is with an ornate gilded pattern of pure sterling silver
Repair-kit containing a set of various micro-circuits. Used by the Military to repair the mobile transmitter located in the Cordon
Large 3 litre Thermos flask with a wide neck. Made from stainless steel, not glass. Keeps a meal warm for a full day
Small 1 litre Thermos flask with a narrow neck. Made from stainless steel, not glass. Keeps liquids hot for half a day
Heavy sledge hammer with a wooden handle. Weight: 25kg
Ordinary 32mm x 36mm wrench. Quite large, heavy, and made of rusty steel. Nothing much else to say about it...
Typical slotted head screwdriver. Nothing remarkable about it, other than it has seen better days back in the U.S.S.R.

Your biggest mistake was to cross Duty, so I'll not waste time with small talk. I'm taking this portable video tranceiver. When I'm done with it I'll leave it near the Army Warehouses - in one of the abandoned houses in the village. If you need it, that's where it'll be\nKirkor Phillips

Portable video conferencing tranceiver with a range of up to 30km. Needs to be hooked up to a computer terminal in order to function properly. Very dated now, but during the Cold War this would have been 'cutting edge' technology...
A computer terminal capable of sending, receiving, and recording voice messages with video from various sources. Used during the Cold War to intercept and decipher messages both foreign and domestic
Army issue mobile tranceiver, capable of sending and receiving messages up to 70km

'Whey' tablets are known throughout the Zone to surpass all known first-aid kits and other medical concoctions for healing wounds and treating various sicknesses. They are extremely rare, and were only distributed amongst the Special Forces 'Spetsnaz' units while on secretive missions throughout the Zone
Not to be confused with the toxic by-product of cheese making, these have a completely different origin. When a vein of iron disulphide, or 'Fools Gold' ran through a section of the anomaly known as 'The Oasis', the entire vein took on the miraculous healing properties of that anomalous area.
The Zone attracts all kinds of people. Some are smart. Others are, shall we say, 'hard of thinking'. Exploring an old mine, a Stalker by the name of Brilliant stumbled upon this Fool's Gold. Thinking it was real, he took a sample to the local scientists to confirm his wealth. Naturally, they recognised it for what it was, but they saw something else too.
After trying to retrieve a Fireball artefact too close to its source, Brilliant's right hand was burned all over. All, that is, except where he had been holding tightly onto his piece of 'gold'. There, was the light pink of new skin forming. After further research they discovered that powdered iron disulphide from this vein mixed with magnesium hydroxide (milk of magnesia) created a highly reparative and restorative solution that could be compacted into small tablets. Not only that, but the gold flecks in the tablets made them look effective, exclusive, and expensive, and they were marketed as 'Oasis' Life Saver tablets.
However, once fast-acting painkillers and euphoriants were added to the formula, the first and last syllables were dropped and they became simply known as 'Whey' Tablets, due to their immediate colloquial effect on the user...
Flash drive containing the information for Kalinin. It has been encrypted, and will require work to decipher and unlock it
The Log Book, passed along to the next shift at the changing of the guard. Within it is written the code to a prisoner's cell: 208568. The rest appears to be barely legible rhetorical crap...
An ordinary bar of fresh, clean soap. Even after all these years in the wastes with everything else, it still appears new and unused. A rare find indeed!

A Monolithian amulet, bestowed upon the 'elite' within the Monolith Faction as a symbol of faithful service. Extremely rare, and hard to come across. Contains 'runic' symbols that appear to be from a long-forgotten language...
Small box containing all the tools necessary to repair and maintain weapons in the Zone. A nice find, and certainly a valuable asset

On the reverse side reads an inscription - 'Master Khabarych'. Inside are papers on which the numbers 434018 and 206018 are written, and a short message:\n'Coded doors in Bunker #3. I have only found two, so that means there must be another - but where? I have heard of a place where there is a safe - still locked, but intact - and within it may lie the answer. The missing code?'\nOther than illegible scribble, there's nothing else inside...

An old fireproof safe, small in size. Covered in rust, but still tightly sealed. It is protected by a coded lock, making it impossible to open without the proper code, or destroying whatever is inside. Contents are unknown but, judging by the weight, it could be empty...

Broken manual teleporter. Originally modified by a guy who's now a hospital patient. It is activated by means of a bio-field, and has a 200 metre radius. Unfortunately, using it can deactivate other teleports nearby...

Broken manual teleporter. Originally modified by a guy who's now a hospital patient. It is activated by means of a bio-field, and has a 200 metre radius. Unfortunately, using it can deactivate other teleports nearby...

Broken manual teleporter. Originally modified by a guy who's now a hospital patient. It is activated by means of a bio-field, and has a 200 metre radius. Unfortunately, using it can deactivate other teleports nearby...

A bag containing medicinal ointments and assorted medical supplies. Although its purpose is unknown, there's nothing extraordinary about it. It should really be given to the Gynecologist, who'll probably find a use for it...
A heavy box, with what appears to be a weapon inside
Unusual tablets. Purpose unknown. Medication, or drug? Best be careful with them...
Unusual tablets. Purpose unknown. Medication, or drug? Best be careful with them...
Unusual tablets. Purpose unknown. Medication, or drug? Best be careful with them...
An old, re-useable syringe. Dirty, already used, and a recipe for disease and infection. Someone would have to be really desperate to use this thing...
An Accumulator. Quite worn out, and almost unusable. How it ended up here is anyone's guess...
Gold pocket watch. Possibly belonging to the old man. In spite of everything it's been through after all this time, and the poor shape it's in, it still works!

Detector capable of identifying all known anomalies. Hard to come by in the Zone, and many skilled Stalkers and faction leaders have only heard of them. Represents an update to the well-known 'Elite' detector developed by the scientists and upgraded by Professor Sakharov. A couple of prototypes were found at the Scientific Research Institute, and another in a dark, deserted cave. They are highly sought after by both military and non-military personnel, and are constantly at risk of being stolen by one side or the other...
A shaving razor. Not particularly sharp, but would certainly do at a pinch, with such simple luxuries very hard to come by...
Computer disk with something written on it. Difficult to tell what, as the markings are almost completely worn away...

%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,255,1,1]+10\n%c[default]\nAn empty flask made from a unusual type of glass. Said to have been hand-blown using minerals from a powdered Mica artefact. Has a specially designed valve, and a protective metal casing. Less clear about it is what it was used for...
A power unit for the Freedom faction's Exoskeleton Armor. Differs from other Exoskeletons in that it has been modified to support an increased socket capacity...

Receipt for a spare circuit board for an old Babineau tape recorder. The price seems high but, as it was manufactured in the old Soviet ideological, pre-perestroika era, the build quality is solid, and will last for many years...

%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,255,1,1]+10\n%c[default]\nA flask with air-tight valves, and filled with a dark blue liquid of unknown origin. When worn on the belt, it can restore both health and energy...

%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,255,1,1]+10\n%c[default]\nA flask with air-tight valves, and filled with a bright orange liquid of unknown origin. When worn on the belt, it can accelerate the healing process by arresting blood loss...

Corpse of the Experienced Controller. Looks as though it died about five days ago, as it's already started to decompose. Strangely, there appears to be no damage to the body... Cause of death: Unknown
What appears to be the head of the trader Sidorovich, made from the head of a Controller. It actually bears an uncanny resemblance to the original, and is somewhat better looking...
Empty flask with air-tight seals. Potentially useful, but nevertheless empty...
Completely full and functional flask. Contains a white liquid with gold flecks - medicinal 'whey'
A tattered child's doll. I wonder who this belonged to. Poor kid...
An old, torn, shabby map from the second World War. Thought to have once belonged to the Stalker known as 'Fang'...
A copy of Fang's map, only without transition markers. Very well made, and obviously the work of an expert cartographer

Greetings. We've heard that the 'Marked One' was pulled from one of the Death Trucks, so listen to me. We know where the ring is, and it's very important to us that we get it back. We'll pay good money, as well as sharing our information with you. We'll also have other things to discuss with you when this is done. I shall send the messenger to you, and you shall tell him where it is...\nOstolom

The Mercenary's Ring. Previously belonging to one of the leaders of this group, who passed it on to one of his few friends before leaving the Zone - a familiar practice of the Mercenary creed. This 'friend' who now has the ring, however - nobody knows nor cares about him...

The Mercenary's Ring. Previously belonging to one of the leaders of this group, who passed it on to one of his few friends before leaving the Zone - a familiar practice of the Mercenary creed. This 'friend' who now has the ring, however - nobody knows nor cares about him...
Deactivated Teleporter in a secret part of the Military Lab. From where it came, and why the key from its bio-field has not worked, are both mysteries...
A stuffed Pseudodog. Possibly made by the ones who managed to kill it. Quite a trophy, that should look good in any base...

Computer disk (containing data). Appears to be in decent condition, but there's no way of knowing until you actually push the thing into a working computer, which is damn near impossible to find in the Zone...

Gold bars which are cast rather than stamped, and usually thicker than stamped bars, are called 'ingots'. This one is indistinctly engraved with the markings of a faction, and probably forged in secret at one of the old laboratories in the Zone...

"I write this in advance, as I do not know what awaits me tomorrow. I came to the Zone like so many others, to seek my fortune. I did not know that here, just as beyond the Zone's perimeter, reigns a filth and treachery so vile that it would eventually become my own undoing. I only ask that whomsoever finds this note... please get it to my family somehow, and tell them that that I love them dearly, and that I shall miss them forever..."\nThere is an address, and also a number scribbled separately - 89115683244. A code, maybe?
PDA containing information on artefact modification

You'll need several things to successfully transmutate an artefact:
1. The Recipe - You must have the correct Recipe for the artefact you're trying to transmute. Hearsay will not be enough!
2. The correct anomaly - Dropping an artefact into the wrong anomaly will achieve absolutely nothing (see the Encyclopedia of Anomalies to identify the right one)
3. The correct artefact - Dropping the wrong artefact will also get you nowhere.
4. The correct time of day - The transmutation MUST be started at night time, between 18:00 and 06:00 hours. As long as you START before 06:00 in the morning it should work - it does NOT need to finish before 06:00
 
E.g. You have the recipe for the Skin artefact. Look up the Skin artefact on the chart and notice the entries under the 'Parent artefact', 'Parent anomaly', and 'Time' headings. These tell you that if you want to make a Skin artefact, open up your inventory and drop a Pellicle artefact into a Springboard anomaly. If you see a bright flash of white light for a second, you'll know that the anomaly has accepted the artefact. If not, then pick up the artefact and stand closer to the anomaly before dropping the artefact in.
Once it's been accepted, simply wait (or sleep) for 5 hours, and see what comes out. If you're lucky, it'll be a Skin artefact. If not, it'll be a Cobblestone - a different type of artefact formed when something beyond your control went wrong with the 'cooking' process - and these artefacts have their own value to collectors.
Finally, bear in mind that nothing is ever easy or straightforward in the Zone, and once the new artefact has been generated, it may not necessarily stay in one place. Many Stalkers regard artefacts as living and even capricious things. Depending on the anomaly, the incline of the ground, the prevailing wind, and the new artefact itself, it may have rolled downhill, be up in the air, hidden itself in the undergrowth, or even wandered off somewhere nearby...

A portable Psi-antenna developed as part of the 'About Consciousness' program, and used for experiments detailing the effects of radiation on live organisms. The unit not only generates and transmits Psi-energy, but also produces a localised hallucinogenic effect. An interesting side effect of the unit is an ability to teleport a variety of the Zone's mutants into its field.\nTo even approach such a powerful aerial array, let alone try to switch it off, without taking the utmost protective measures against Psi-radiation and the local fauna, would be the equivalent of a harrowing death wish. The unit has an effective radius of up to 70 metres
Documents found by hunters in the Red Forest
A common toughened backpack, but fitted with a combination lock. Useful for keeping things safe from opportunistic thieves and other unsavoury characters that inhabit the Zone...

Military issue hand-radio. Reception ranges is up to 10km with clear line of sight. Useful for long range communication with others throughout the Zone, but it's anyone's guess who might be listening in...

Military issue hand-radio. Reception range is up to 10km with clear line of sight. Useful for long range communication with others throughout the Zone, but anybody with access to the same standard frequency could be listening in...

Although slightly radioactive, the Amanita mushroom is edible after prolonged boiling - but be warned. A common ingredient in the manufacture of potent tranquilizers and pain medication, it's often used by local drug addicts for its variety of hallucinegenic effects. It grows mostly in marshland, and has a tendency to disintegrate if kept for too long once plucked from the ground

Instantaneous Spatial Transfer Device with a faulty coordinate plane circuit, this unit will provide instant, albeit indiscriminate, teleportation when your choices are limited to staying where you are, or being somewhere else... Use only in extreme cases, when you need to be anywhere but here!
A one-use teleport, which requires a 'Moonlight' artefact to energize it. If you want another, see Professor Sakharov, who'll require a 'Battery' artefact to build and configure a replacement...
%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,255,1,1]+10\n%c[default]\nSpecial Goldfish artefact in the Cordon. Kostya is looking for this particular one...
PDA found in a hiding place in the Cordon. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place at the Garbage. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place in Laboratory X-18. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place in Yantar. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place at Agroprom. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place at the Army Warehouses. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place at Radar. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place in Pripyat. Important data transferred...
PDA found in a hiding place in Laboratory X-10. Contains one, singularly important entry: 'Code decryption complete: 2... 9... 7... Good luck, Stalker!'

Folder containing rare documents from Laboratory X-10. A veritable treasure trove of raw information. Includes practical details on how a Teleporter functions, and a complete list of the esoteric equipment required to build one. What the hell were these people up to? And who organized them to come here in the first place...?
PDA containing valuable scientific information. Obtained from Laboratory X-16

Videocassette with the protection tab snapped off. Contents as yet unknown but, for one reason or another, the Military want to get their hands on it. More than likely contains archive information on the Zone's formation, and other confidential stuff. I'll exchange it with Sakharov for a Minigun, and wash my hands of it. The less I know, the better I'll sleep...
Special detector designed by Sakharov to locate a specific RFID tag, and deliberately restricted to a radius of ten metres for security purposes, so you need to know where to start looking...
Photo of the Monolith with erased but coded figures...

%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,1,255,1]-20\n%c[default]\n'Isomorphic' Globe, of a strange and undetermined origin. Putting it inside a backpack will reduce the combined radiation level of all artefacts being carried...
The main body of the 'Special' camera

%c[1,1,1,1]______ %c[255,255,255,255]Radiation %c[255,255,1,1]+10\n%c[default]\n'Isomorphic' camera lens. Wearing it on the belt has the negative side effect of increasing radiation dosage, due to the unique coating on the lens...
Shutter for the camera. A modified 'Unique' Desert Eagle is required to make use of it...

Anomalous Chernomor sniper rifle based on the Walther WA 2000 design. Significantly reduced weight and wear due to the change induced at molecular level by an as-yet unknown Isomorphic element. Computerized sight, with a homemade high-capacity clip. But most importantly - a weapon capable of firing abnormal 7.62x54mm rounds...
Pack of letters belonging to the Rookie Stalker. Poorly scribbled in pencil, and of no great literary interest. They seem to be covered in the foul smelling slime from a Flesh's stomach...

Plastic explosive (aka Plastique) is a specialized form of explosive material that is soft and mouldable by hand. Common plastic explosives include Semtex and C-4. Within the field of explosives engineering, plastic explosives are known as 'putty explosives'. They are especially suited for explosive demolition work, as they can be easily formed into the best shapes for 'cutting' through structural members, and have a high enough density and velocity of detonation to penetrate steel. Generally, they are unsuitable for ordinary blasting since they are significantly more expensive than other materials which perform just as well in that field. Also, when an explosive is combined with a plasticizer to create a putty explosive, its power is generally lower than that of the explosive alone

'Isomorphic' Plastique (C-4). Soft putty explosive which can be moulded into the most effective shape for the job. Plastic explosives tend to be safe from accidental detonation by fire and impact, requiring an independent detonator and an electrical charge to set it off. This convenience and safety make them ideal for Military applications, and the higher relative costs that makes it unsuitable for commercial blasting also keeps it out of the hands of the general population
A standard length of synthetic rope. Could really come in useful here in the Zone...
Bomb casing. Although both the warhead and its detonator are missing...
Artefact Merger. Its origin is unknown...
Photograph of the Rookie Village in the Cordon
Photograph of the Rookie Village in the Cordon
Description of a hiding place in an attic
Description of a hiding place in an attic
In order to view this photograph, insert it into the sidearm slot...
Appears to be a master key for a certain range of models of Armored vehicle
